name: Seville
fun_fact: Seville is the birthplace of tapas! The word 'tapa' means 'lid' - small plates were originally used to cover wine glasses to keep out flies. The city has over 31,000 orange trees producing 4 million kilos of oranges annually, and the spring air smells like orange blossoms. Plus, the Royal Alc√°zar is still in use by the Spanish royal family!

hero_dishes.name: Tapas
hero_dishes.description: Small plates of various dishes meant for sharing - from jam√≥n ib√©rico to tortilla de camarones (shrimp fritters) to salmorejo
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in Andalusia, possibly by King Alfonso XIII who required food with drinks due to illness, or from placing bread and ham on glass lids to keep out insects. Seville transformed this into a cherished dining tradition as the capital of the region.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Rinconcillo (founded 1670, Seville's oldest bar), Las Teresas 1870 (in Santa Cruz neighborhood), Casa Morales (traditional bodega since 1850), Las Golondrinas (in Triana)

hero_dishes.name: Salmorejo
hero_dishes.description: Cold tomato soup thicker than gazpacho, topped with hard-boiled egg and jam√≥n serrano
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional Andalusian dish that's heartier than gazpacho, perfect for hot Seville summers
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every authentic tapas bar serves this - especially good at El Rinconcillo

hero_dishes.name: Solomillo al Whisky
hero_dishes.description: Succulent pork tenderloin in tangy whisky-garlic sauce, often served with crispy potatoes
hero_dishes.origin_story: A popular Sevillian specialty found in practically every tapas bar - the whisky sauce is distinctive to Seville
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Widespread in local tapas bars throughout the city

hero_dishes.name: Espinacas con Garbanzos
hero_dishes.description: Spinach and chickpeas stewed with garlic, cumin, and paprika
hero_dishes.origin_story: Classic Andalusian tapa with Moorish influences from centuries of Islamic rule
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Rinconcillo specializes in this traditional dish

hero_dishes.name: Cola de Toro
hero_dishes.description: Braised oxtail in rich red wine sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Reflects Seville's bullfighting heritage - using every part of the bull in traditional cooking
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Found at traditional tapas bars and restaurants throughout Seville

hero_dishes.name: Tortilla de Camarones
hero_dishes.description: Crispy, lacy fritters made with tiny shrimp, parsley, and onion
hero_dishes.origin_story: A specialty of C√°diz province but beloved throughout Andalusia
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Most authentic tapas bars serve these crispy delights

signature_drinks.name: Fino Sherry
signature_drinks.description: Dry, pale fortified wine from nearby Jerez
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served cold in small copitas (glasses) as the perfect aperitif with tapas, especially jam√≥n and olives

signature_drinks.name: Tinto de Verano
signature_drinks.description: Red wine mixed with lemon soda or gaseosa
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The locals' summer refresher - lighter and more popular than sangria (which is touristy)

signature_drinks.name: Rebujito
signature_drinks.description: Manzanilla sherry mixed with lemon-lime soda
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The drink of Feria de Abril (April Fair) - refreshing and dangerously easy to drink
